sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: The purpose was to analyze our trauma population during two periods to assess for predictors of recidivism.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Prior (2007–2011, n = 879) and recent (2014–2019, n = 954) orthopaedic trauma patients were reviewed. Recidivists were those returning with an unrelated injury. Recidivism rates were compared, and factors associated with recidivism were identified.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Recidivism decreased: 18.7% to 14.3% (p = 0.01). Mean age and sex of the two cohorts were not different. Recent recidivists were more likely to sustain gunshot wound (GSW) injuries (22.1% vs 18.9%, p = 0.09), and mental illness was more common (56.6% vs 28.1%, p < 0.0001). The recent recidivist population was less often married (12.9% vs 23.8%, p = 0.03), and both recidivist groups were often underinsured (Medicaid or uninsured: (60.6% vs 67.0%)).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Recidivism diminished, although more GSW and mental illness were seen. Recidivists are likely to be underinsured. The changing profile of recidivists may be attributed to socioeconomic trends and new programs to improve outcomes after trauma.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Trauma patients have been shown to exhibit recidivism frequently, resulting in new traumatic injuries, seen in subsequent visits to emergency rooms [1–5]. These visits and resultant hospital admissions generate substantial medical and interpersonal costs. Literature shows approximately 15–20% of patients sustaining an orthopaedic injury will have at least one subsequent unrelated injury [1, 4, 6–8]. Previous studies have analyzed demographic, social, and injury factors associated with recidivism, such as male sex [1–4, 7, 9], alcohol use [4, 9–13], and unmarried status [1, 4, 8]. However, few have assessed changes in recidivism rates and patient populations over time.

With the advent and closure of trauma centers, and changing patient demographics and social determinants of health, the overall trauma patient population and recidivist profile may change. The purposes of this study are to describe these factors within the current trauma population at our level 1 center and to compare with a similar group of injured patients who presented eight years prior and were previously characterized[4]. Rates of recidivism will be compared for the two groups, and risk factors for recidivism will be identified along with changes in risk profile over time.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: This review included two cohorts of adult orthopaedic trauma patients treated surgically for high energy fractures of the pelvis, acetabulum, proximal or diaphyseal femur, or thoracolumbar spine at a level one trauma center. The prior group presented between 2007 and 2011 (n = 879) with their index injury, while the recent group first presented between 2014 and 2019 (n = 954). Recidivism was defined as a new, unrelated injury event resulting in care in the emergency department within the time period through January 1, 2013 for the first group, and January 1, 2021 for the more recent group.

Demographic information was recorded, and social history including marital status, employment status, highest formal education level, health insurance coverage, and utilization of recreational substances were collected. Recidivism rates were compared, and multivariate regression analysis was used to assess potential injury, demographic, or social factors associated with recidivism.

sec.title: Comparison of recent versus prior trauma patients
sec.p:
The mean age and sex of the two study groups was unchanged, with a majority being male (Table 1). The most common mechanism of injury across both cohorts was motor vehicle collision (MVC) (40.7% recent vs 48.8% prior). Substantial increase in gunshot injuries was noted (12.9% recent vs 6.8% prior, p < 0.001); other forms of assault also increased over time. Pre-existing mental illness also became more common over time, reported in 36.2% of recent patients versus 21.5% of prior patients (p < 0.0001). See Table 2. However, both tobacco smoking and recreational drug use were less common in the recent cohort (44.0% and 36.7%, respectively) compared with the early cohort (53.5% (p = 0.002) and 46.6% (p = 0.001)). sec.title: Recidivism rates
sec.p: Over time, recidivism rates between the two treatment cohorts decreased from 18.7% to 14.3% (p = 0.01). Severity of new injuries was similar over time, as the groups had comparable rates of hospital admission for recidivist emergency department presentation (recent 22.1% vs prior 23.8%). For those patients admitted to the hospital, lengths of hospital stay were also similar (recent 3.6 days versus 3.8 days prior). However, mean time to recidivism was greater in the prior cohort (34.2 months vs 20.8 months).

Factors associated with recidivism were compared between the two groups. Notably, recent recidivists were more likely to sustain GSW injuries (22.1% vs 18.9% of recidivists, p = 0.09), comprising 30 of 123 recent GSW patients (38%), versus 23 of 60 prior GSW patients (24%, p = 0.057). Mental illness was twice as common among recent recidivists compared with prior (56.6% vs 28.1%, p < 0.0001). Depression was the most common mental health diagnosis among recent recidivists, occurring in 26%. However, alcohol intoxication on arrival was more common in the prior group (32.4% vs 20.6%, p = 0.03) as was recreational drug use (79.2% vs 28.7%, p < 0.0001). The recent recidivist population was more likely to have completed high school (79.5% vs 69.1%, p = 0.11), more likely to be unmarried (87.1% vs 76.2.%, p = 0.03), and more likely to be disabled (13.2% vs 2.1%, p < 0.001), though similarly likely to be underinsured (60.6% vs 67.0%, p = 0.53). An underinsured status was one of the most common characteristics of the recidivism groups.

sec.title: Repeat recidivism
sec.p: Of note, some patients had more than one recidivist presentation, each with a new injury event. In comparison of multiple recidivists, the prior group had 72 multiple recidivists (8.2% of all patients, 44.4% of recidivists), while the recent group had 69 multiple recidivists (7.2% of all patients, 50.7% of recidivists). No significant differences were noted between these groups.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Previously we reported factors associated with recidivism among operative orthopaedic trauma patients [4]. Both the current and historical cohorts had the same inclusion criteria: operative spine, pelvis, acetabulum, proximal and/or diaphyseal femur fracture in adult patients. Specific demographic and injury factors identified included male sex, younger age (mean 37 years), and GSW mechanism. In that cohort, tobacco smoking, alcohol on presentation, alcohol intoxication, recreational drug use, mental illness, unemployment, and underinsured status were also highly associated with trauma recidivism. The more recent group resembled the initial trauma population, although some significant demographic and social differences were noted. Recidivism decreased over time, but remained high, at 14% within a mean of 21 months following the index injury, which was earlier than the mean time to recidivism in the prior group.

In the recent study group mean age and distribution of sex were no different over time, although current recidivists were slightly younger and were more often male. This is consistent with the GSW population, which doubled in number in the more recent group [14–17]. Among other risk factors for recidivism, the entire trauma population experienced significant increases in pre-existing mental illness, single marital status, disability preventing employment, and a trend toward more underinsured status. Although recreational substances were used less often among the current trauma population, recreational drug use and tobacco smoking remained associated with trauma recidivism. A portion of the decreased rate of recidivism may relate to less recreational substance use and abuse more recently [10, 18].

Both groups had rates of recidivism consistent with findings of other authors [1, 4, 6–9, 19]. Key associations with recidivism have been consistent across much of this work. Married status is increasingly less common in the United States and unmarried status is an established risk factor for recidivism [1, 4, 8]. Unemployed patients were more common in our prior recidivist cohort, and this is a known association with trauma recidivism [1, 2, 4, 20]. Of note, disabled patients were more likely recidivists currently, a phenomenon that has not been described to our knowledge.

The increase in GSW injuries resembles reports from other US trauma centers [14–17]. Brooke et al. found recidivist patients with penetrating injuries to be more likely to have a similar injury on repeat visit and also had an increased risk of death [6]. These injuries are likely to be associated with recidivists having the same mechanism of injury on repeat visit, and a high risk of complications and readmissions [4, 15, 19, 21]. Thirty-eight percent of our prior cohort of GSW patients experienced recidivism, compared to 24% of the current cohort. While firearm violence has become more common, the frequency of recidivism in that group may be decreasing over time at our trauma center, which is encouraging.

Mental illness has also been increasing in the United States, even prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has greatly accentuated this tendency [14, 22]. We noted over half of our recidivists had mental illness, and the rate of mental illness among recidivists doubled when our two study groups were compared. Ramifications, in addition to recidivism, include lower rates of employment, greater risks for complications, more chronic pain, and lower patient satisfaction among patients with pre-existing mental illness [4, 20, 23–29]. Resources to treat this patient population are lacking in most trauma systems, and this remains a major public health issue [5, 14, 17, 30–38].

Limitations of this study include the retrospective nature of data collection, and its inherent likelihood of recall bias and underreporting baseline social factors. Another limitation is the inclusion criteria of operative spine, pelvis, acetabulum or femur fracture. A wider inclusion set may generate a different rate of trauma recidivism. That being said, the inclusion criteria were the same for both the current and the historical cohorts. A related limitation is that elderly patients with new fractures are becoming more frequent, as the population ages and the life span increases; yet, this study did not address these patients, and our findings may not be relevant to this important group. Strengths include our large sample size. Although patients may have been recidivists in other hospitals, our electronic medical record was able to identify encounters within other health systems using that record system, and where our patients may have received care.

In conclusion, although recidivism has decreased over time; it remains staggering to our healthcare system that 14% are returning with a new injury event at a mean of 20 months later. Of these, 22% are admitted to the hospital with a new injury. Over 60% of this group are underinsured, resulting in massive medical costs borne by the trauma system, beyond the detriment to these patients and their families. Many risk factors for recidivism worsened over time, including mental illness, unmarried status, and gunshot injuries. These resemble medical and socioeconomic trends in our nation. Implementation of programs to improve patient outcomes after trauma may be contributing to lower rates of recidivism. These services and more emphasis on identification and treatment of mental illness, along with violence intervention programs appear warranted. Further study of such programming may delineate effectiveness in mitigating this growing burden.
